Title: Palatini action
Explanation: The metric and connection are independent. Variation not on the connection. Note the new Ricci tensor is constructed with an independent connection:  $Re=g_{munu}R_{munu}$.

Title: Total action
Explanation: Total action for a metric $f(R)$.

Title: F(R*,Lm)
Explanation: The action is a function of the affine Ricci scalar and the matter Lagrangian.

Title: F(R*,T)
Explanation: The action is a function of the affine Ricci scalar and the trace of the energy momentum tensor.

Title: F(R,Lm)
Explanation: The action is a function of the Ricci scalar and the matter Lagrangian.

Title: F(R,T)
Explanation: The action is a function of the Ricci scalar and the trace of the energy momentum tensor.

Title: Temporal geometry constraint
Explanation: This field equation imposes a constraint on the temporal geometry, specifying that it remains unaffected by the Riemann curvature tensor $K$.

Title: $R=Const<0$
Explanation: Ricci scalar is constant and negative at all points.

Title: $R=Const>0$
Explanation: Ricci scalar is constant and positive at all points.
Riemann’s curvature tensor of the affine connection is zero. Found as $K=0$ in Friedman. It is one of Trautman’s homogenous condition.
Covariant derivative of $dt$ equals zero to ensure the simultaneity slices are flat.
Condition that preserves angles and distances when parallel transporting along a curve.
Covariant derivative of h describes euclidean geometry.
Covariant derivative of V equals zero. It makes the lines in the rigging of space-time to be geodesics.

Title: $dt(V)=1$
Explanation: Derivative of $V=0$ makes the lines in the rigging of space-time to be timelike.

Title: $f(R)=R$
Explanation: The function dependent on the Ricci scalar is of first order.

Title: $f(R)neqR$
Explanation: The function dependent on the Ricci scalar is of high order.

Title: $f(Re)=Re$
Explanation: The function of the affine curvature scalar is of first order

Title: $f(Re)neqRe$
Explanation: The function of the affine curvature scalar is of high order

Title: $f’(R)=1$
Explanation: The first derivative of the function dependent on the Ricci scalar is one.

Title: $f’’(R) =0$
Explanation: The second derivative of the function of the Ricci scalar is zero.

Title: $f’’(R)≠-0$
Explanation: The second derivative of the function of the Ricci scalar is not zero.

Title: $f''(Re)=0$
Explanation: The second derivative of the function of the affine curvature scalar is zero.

Title: $f''(Re)neq0$
Explanation: The second derivative of the function of the affine curvature scalar is not zero.
An orthogonality condition that describes euclidean geometry.

Title: $lambda(phi)=0$
Explanation: Nordtvedt's (1970b) scalar-tensor theory is equivalent to the Bergmann-Wagoner theory in the special case of zero cosmological function $lambdaequiv0$

Title: Locality
Explanation: Matter is a point function.

Title: Non metricity tensor vanishes
Explanation: Homogeneous Trautman condition.

Title: Non-locality
Explanation: Matter is a function of density.

Title: $R=0$
Explanation: The Ricci scalar is zero.

Title: $R=Const.$
Explanation: The Ricci scalar is constant.

Title: $T_{munu}rightarrow0$: Dust
Explanation: Energy momentum tensor is almost zero; models for dust.

Title: $tau=0$
Explanation: In this case, no constraint is placed on the vector field.

Title: $tau=1$
Explanation: This represents a constraint on the gauge of the vector field $k_{mu}$ imposed by the lack of full gauge invariance of the action $I$.

Title: Cartan torsion tensor vanishes
Explanation: Homogeneous Trautman Condition $widetilde{R}_{bd}^{ac}=widetilde{R}_{db}^{ca}$.

Title: $C_{0}$, $C_{1}$: Cosmological matching parameters
Explanation: In the universe rest frame, g then has the asymptotic form $diag(-c_{0},c_{1},c_{1},c_{1})$, where $c_{0}$ and $c_{1}$  may vary on a Hubble timescale.

Title: $lambda(phi)$: Cosmological function
Explanation: $lambda(phi)$ causes two effects: in the field equation for $g$ it plays the same role as the cosmological constant in GR, and, in the field equation, it gives $(phi)$ a range l related to $lambda$, $w$ and their derivatives, in the sense that the solutions for $(phi)$ for an isolated system contain Yukawa-like terms $expleft(-r/lright)$.

Title: $phi_{0}$: Cosmological matching parameter
Explanation: For chosen values for $r$ and $q$, the present values of $w$ and $Lambda$ are determined by the asymptotic value $phi_{0}$, which in turn is found through a cosmological solution using the theory.

Title: Milgrom’s constant $a_{0}approx1.2times10^{-10}m/s^{2}$
Explanation: Acceleration scale

Title: Einstein’s field equation
Explanation: Matter tells space how tu curve, and Curvature tells matter how to move.

Title: Field equation for Mond local F(R,T)
Field Equation for Mond non local pure Metric
Palatini field equation 2
Explanation: ($bar{nabla}_{lambda}$) is the covariant derivative defined with the independent connection.

Title: Field Equation for Mond local pure Metric
Field Equation
Explanation: Field equation after varying independently with respect to the connection.

Title: Field Equation
Explanation: Field equation after varying independently with respect to the Lagrange multiplier.

Title: Field Equation
Explanation: The field equation is derived from the action 5-30.

Title: Field equation for BSLL bimetric theory
Field Equation for Mond non local Palatini

Explanation: If the Ricci scalar $R=0$, then the field equation reduces to $R_{mueta}=0$.

If the Ricci scalar $R=const.$, then the field equation reduces to $R_{munu}=g_{munu}frac{C}{4}$, and the maximally symmetric solution is de Sitter or anti-de Sitter space depending on the sign of the constant.

If the Ricci scalar $R=cte$, then the field equation reduces to $R_{munu}=g_{munu}frac{C}{4}$, and the maximally symmetric solution is de Sitter or anti-de Sitter space depending on the sign of the constant.

Title: Poisson’s Eq
Explanation: Poisson's field equation relates the gravitational potential $Phi$ with the mass density $rho$, where $del(Phi)$ is the divergence of the gradient of $Phi$, and k is the newtonian gravitational constant.

Title: Poisson’s Eq in curved space
Explanation: Poisson's field equation in curved space relates the Ricci tensor of the connection with the mass density.

Title: Arbitrary functions
Explanation: This functions help build algebraically the metric tensor and the action.

Title: $tau$: Arbitrary parameter
Explanation: This represents a constraint on the gauge of the vector field $k_{mu}$ imposed by the lack of full gauge invariance of the action $I$.

Title: $Gamma$: Affine connection
Explanation: A generalised connection for vector fields in curved spaces where torsion and non-metricity are not necessarily zero, telling us about straitest curve.

Title: $B$: Symmetric tensor field
Explanation: The symmetric tensor field $B$ is typically associated with the presence of multiple metrics, which describe how distances and intervals are measured in different ways. In stratified and bimetric theories there might be two or more metrics to describe different aspects of gravity or spacetime such as variations in gravity's strength or range. $B$ helps relate and reconcile these metrics, ensuring that the theory remains self-consistent.

Title: $Riem(Gamma)$: Riemann curvature tensor
Explanation: This geometric object is used to quantify the intrinsic curvature of a space. It has several components expressed in terms of partial derivatives of the affine connection (Found as K in Friedman, 1983)

Title: $dt$: Time function
Explanation: Co-vector that induces a foliation of $M$ into three-dimensional hyper surfaces.

Title: $eta$: Minkowski’s metric
Explanation: Flat non-dynamical metric. Since $Riem(gamma)=0$, we can always choose global coordinates in which $eta_{munu}=diag(-1,1,1,1)$.

Title: $overline{nabla}$: Flat connection
Explanation: A derivative for flat spaces.

Title: $h$: Flat Metric tensor
Explanation: A symmetric tensor field of type $(2,0)$. h is defined on de cotangent space $T_{p}^{*}times T_{p}^{*}$ and has signature $<3,0,1>$. It induces a three-dimensional metric on each hypersurface.

Title: Hypermomentum
Explanation: A quantity representing the variation of SM with respect to the connection, which mimics the definition of the stress-energy tensor.

Title: $K^{mu}$: Dynamical vector field
Explanation: (assumed timelike)

Title: $Gamma*$: Metric-Affine connection
Explanation: A connection for Metric-affine spaces where non-metricity and torsion are not zero.

Title: $left{ _{munu}^{lambda}right} $: Metric connection
Explanation: Also called Levi-Civita connection, it is dependent on the metric $g$. It gives us information about how to transport vectors along a curve, while conserving the metric.

Title: $g_{munu}$: Metric tensor
Explanation: A symmetric tensor field of type $(0,2)$ and signature $<1,3>$. Provides a sense of distance and angles between vectors telling us about shortest curve.

Title: $nabla$: Newton-Cartan Connection
Explanation: Non-flat covariant connection. In Friedman it is found as $D$.

Title: Non metricity tensor
Explanation: It measures the failure of the connection to covariantly conserve the metric.

Title: $phi$: Dynamical scalar field
Explanation: Rest masses of elementary particles are allowed to vary in spacetime via a dynamical scalar field $phi$.

Title: $t$: Cosmic time function
Explanation: A nondynamical scalar field. The gradient of $t$ is covariantly constant and timelike with respect to $eta$. This scalar field selects out preferred spatial sections of “strata” in the universe that are orthogonal to $nabla$.

Title: $T$: Stress-Energy-Momentum tensor field
Explanation: Symmetric tensor field $(2,0)$.

Title: Cartan torsion tensor
Explanation: The anti-symmetric part of the connection.

Title: $V$: Contra vector field
Explanation: Describes absolute space. $T_{sigma}=V$ along $sigma$.

Title: Weyl vector
Explanation: The Weyl vector is the trace of the non-metricity tensor with respect to its last two (symmetric) indices.

Title: Medoza’s tensor $chi_{munu}:=L_{M}^{2}R_{munu}$
Explanation: Where $L_{M}^{2}$ defines a length fixed by the parameters of the theory.

Title: $Phi$: Gravitational potential
Explanation: Potential produced by a space-type vector field that represents the gravitational field.

Title: M: Differentiable manifold
Explanation: A topological space that resembles euclidean space near each point. It can be coordinatized by Rn through a family of homeomorphisms.

Title: Equation of motion for Mond non local pure metric
Equation of motion for Mond non local Palatini
Equation of motion for Mond F(R,T)
Equation of motion for Mond local pure metric
Geodesic Law
Explanation: Free particles follow timeline geodesics of the connection.

Title: Gravitational Force
Explanation: Particles acted on only by gravitational forces follow non geodesic paths determined by the gravitational potential.

Title: Signature for the metric tensor
Explanation: The signature contains one positive and three negative index. There are GR models with different signatures.

Title: Signature for the flat tensor h
Explanation: Indicating there are 3 spatial dimensions, 0 negative eigenvalues associated with the metric tensor, indicating it is positive definite in the spatial dimensions. The third number (1) indicates the number of negative eigenvalues associated with the metric tensor in the time dimension, suggesting time is treated differently from space in terms of its signature.

Title: Signature
Explanation: Signature for the metric tensor is definite-positive.

Title: Dependency
Explanation: The connection $Gamma_{munu}^{lambda}$  and the metric tensor $g_{munu}$  depend on each other.

Title: Independency between variables
Explanation: The connection $Gamma_{munu}^{lambda}$ may be expressed independently of the metric tensor $g_{munu}$.

Title: Dimension: $N=4$
Explanation: The dimension of a vector space is the cardinality of a base of $M$.

Title: Signature
Explanation: for the metric tensor: Not-definite-positive $<-,+,+,+>$ or $<+,-,-,->$.
